Scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75. Extrude the sketch along the normal by a distance of 0.5 units. This part has the same width and height as the first part, but the length is 0.75 units.</description>

Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch with a new coordinate system having the following parameters: * Euler Angles: -90°, 0°, -90° * Translation Vector: 0.2496, 0, 0 9. Extrude the 3D sketch with a depth of 0.0624 units in the normal direction and 0.0624 units in the opposite direction. prompt: <description>**Part 1: Three-Dimensional Rectangular Prism** Construct a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The sides are parallel and the top and bottom faces are perpendicular to the sides. The dimensions of the sides are equal and the height is half the width. Begin by creating a new coordinate system. Set the Euler angles to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and the Translation Vector to [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. This will be the basis for creating the 2D sketch. 1. Sketching the Rectangular Prism: Draw a 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. a. Start by drawing line 1: From point [0.0, 0.0] to point [0.2258, 0.0]. b. For line 2, draw from point [0.2258, 0.0] to point [0.2258, 0.75]. c. Draw line 3: From point [0.2258, 0.75] to point [0.0, 0.75]. d. For line 4, draw from point [0.0, 0.75] to point [0.0, 0.0]. The face formed by these lines is face_1. Loop_1 is formed by lines 1 through 4, now closed by the software. 2. Scaling the 2D Sketch: Apply a sketch scale transformation with a scaling factor of 0.75, to the 2D sketch to get the desired dimensions for the prism's sides. 3. Transforming the Scaled 2D Sketch into a 3D Sketch: Perform a transformation on the now-scaled 2D sketch using the rotation information from the coordinate system's euler_angles property, to obtain the 3D sketch. 4. Extruding the 2D sketch into a 3D Model: Extrude the 2D sketch by a depth of 0.5572 (half the width) along the normal direction of the sketch. This will create a three-dimensional rectangular prism. With these instructions, you can create part_1 using the given dimensions, shapes, constraints, and operations, resulting in a final shape as described in the CAD Assembly JSON.</description>
